page.title: 04WORCESTERSHIRE CONSERVATION
page.content:
In the 1960s and 1970s, farmers could control weed growth by spraying with chemicals which attacked broad-leaved plants but left grasses and cereals unharmed. However, the plants killed were indigenous varieties in danger of being lost for ever. Also threatened were the animals, birds and insects whose lives depended on them.
Public disapproval led to the formation of the Worcestershire Nature Conservation Trust, dedicated to acquiring land and conserving its natural growth. In 1979 it bought the 3/4 acre Drake Street Meadow Reserve, grid ref. 802398, where grow 75 species of lowland meadow flowers and ferns including green winged orchid, adders tongue fern, burnet and pepper saxifrage, cowslip, bluebell, wood violet, and dogs mercury.
